cdm.description: The Plan Canonical Data Model represents how pharmacy and medical benefits are structured, priced, and administered within a PBM operating in a passthrough model. It unifies plan design, benefits, networks, coverage rules, and group-level configuration. It must support both standard PBM plans and the added complexity of specialty drug management and care coordination programs.

ncpdp_general_standards.name: Formulary and Benefit (F&B) Standard
ncpdp_general_standards.reasoning: Primary plan-modeling standard for PBM/eRx that defines plan formulary, tiers, coverage status, utilization management rules (PA, step therapy, quantity limits), day-supply variations, and benefit cost-sharing constructs (copay/co-insurance by tier). It yields core entities/attributes for Plan, Formulary, FormularyDrug, Tier, CoverageRule, and BenefitDesign needed to represent how benefits are structured and administered.

ncpdp_general_standards.name: Real-Time Prescription Benefit (RTPB) Standard
ncpdp_general_standards.reasoning: Defines the data model for plan benefit design and pricing as exposed at the point of prescribing, including benefit stage/phase indicators, patient-pay components (copay, deductible, coinsurance), allowed amounts, pharmacy network/channel distinctions (retail, mail, specialty), and coverage restrictions (PA/QL/ST). Even though responses are member-specific, the schema encodes plan-level constructs (benefit phases, accumulator types, network attributes) essential to model pricing and coverage rules in a passthrough PBM.

ncpdp_general_standards.name: Health Care Identification Card – Pharmacy Standard
ncpdp_general_standards.reasoning: Defines canonical plan identification attributes used across PBM plan design and group configuration: RxBIN, RxPCN, RxGrp, Cardholder ID, plan/payer/processor identifiers, and contact data. These are foundational Plan and Group-level keys that unify routing/identification across networks and coverage rules in the CDM.

ncpdp_assessment.notes: For the Plan CDM, NCPDP F&B and RTPB directly model formulary, tiering, coverage rules, benefit phases, network distinctions, and cost-sharing components—core plan entities/attributes. SCRIPT itself is transactional (eRx, ePA) and not primarily plan-modeling, so it is excluded here. Compared to HL7 FHIR (e.g., InsurancePlan and the US Drug Formulary IG), NCPDP provides pharmacy-specific benefit/price constructs (tiers, UM flags, patient pay breakdowns, accumulator/phase semantics) that are critical to PBM plan modeling, while FHIR offers broader cross-domain plan abstractions that can complement but not replace NCPDP detail for pharmacy benefits.
